In the worst-case global economy could stop, similar to what happened with covid but probably worse.

A cyberwar could compromise systems such as:
- Power generation and distribution
- Telecommunications
- Satellites
- Health systems
- Agriculture and water distribution
- Enterprise digital infrastructures
- Global commerce

When talking about cyberwar we think of websites first.

But that's just the tip.

We've never been so dependent on the internet and electronics as now.

A global cyberwar would be much worse than the pandemic.

No state and no citizen is prepared and we have never experienced something like this.

We don't even have lessons learned from the past.

No one is prepared.

So we're actually seeing competition on the TX side of the Ethereum ecosystem!
By providing a feature to the users, they're incentiviced to send the transactions privately to them.
Until now, most miners competed between them for getting their blocks mined but this approach is different.

Why would they do that?

If you don't know, miners get block rewards. Their work is compensated with ether.

This new RPC competes with the public mempool for your transactions.

The advantage is that they promise to protect you from flashbots.

So it seems we will have now competition for our transactions too!

One relevant example would be Etherscan, containing all information of the Ethereum blockchain.
Block explorers contain all blocks, transactions, address and for the case of smart contract platforms often the code and a way to interact with those.
Block explorers are basically a website that shows all activity on the blockchain in a friendly way.
Block explorers are a key tool for both users and developers of blockchains.

Web2 powers the distribution leg.

Web3 powers the trade leg.

Web2 allowed people to skip media companies and go direct to consumers through platforms.

Web3 allows people to skip intermediaries to trade with consumers through protocols.

RT @cortesja: In the last 50 years, technological advancements have made human progress more than anyone could imagine.

But it feels like neutral, decentralized, and programable money would be part of the tech stack of an upgraded version of human coordination.

That's why crypto is important.
I don't know how to fix that or what is the best solution.
States aren't even agile when a catastrophic event like a pandemic hits the world.

Laws can't follow the pace of technological advancements.

Education can't keep up with what's really relevant.

Governments' incentives aren't always clear or aren't even aligned with the needs of the population.
But it feels like the main human coordination mechanisms (states) haven't changed that much or improved.
In the last 50 years, technological advancements have made human progress more than anyone could imagine.

- Creating a community
- Investing into or supporting a creator
- Play to earn games

RT @cortesja: üî∑ NFT Meta Thread üî∑

Curated list of NFT related threads, explainers and articles.

üßµ ‚§µÔ∏è

The message is:

Using NFTs you don't have copyrights of commercially is no different than doing the same with plain JPEGS on the internet.

People could've commercially used those images before but he wouldn't realize as they're probably printed somewhere he can't get access to or just can't even know where.

With NFTs everyone can see it and it's easy to check.

No one can stop people downloading copyrighted images and using them in their designs, or downloading copyrighted materials from P2P networks.

You just have to live with it.

But it's bad that people can make money using other person's work.

How do we stop it?

We can't.

They value driver on NFT space is provenance.

If you're the original author, even if someone mints it and gets some money from it, it usually won't be as relevant as if minted from you.

It's a very subtle difference but it matters a lot.

That subtle difference is a key feature of NFTs. 

Unless you lose your keys or get scammed with a fake transaction, no one can steal your NFTs.

Art has always been stolen.

But people need to understand that minting something you don't own copyrights of is not stealing.

It's a non-allowed commercial usage.
